coredata.dc:title: Tunable structure and dynamics of solid electrolyte interphase at lithium metal anode

Shen, Zhen-Zhen

Wen, Rui
Wan, Li-Jun
coredata.dc:description: Interfacial processes of lithium (Li) deposition and solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation are key determinants of the safety and performance in high-energy Li metal batteries. With the vigorous growth of effective strategies for stabilizing the interfaces, high-resolution and in situ characterization techniques are contemporaneously needed for probing and regulating the underlying mechanisms of these two processes and their interrelation. Therefore, we introduce in situ atomic force microscopy (AFM) that enables direct observation of the nanoscale morphology and dynamic evolution of the Li/electrolyte interfaces in working environments. Inhomogeneous SEI with nanoparticles (NPs) forms in traditional electrolyte, which extends with chain-like wrinkles as dendrite nucleates. By precisely controlling the concentration of lithium nitrate additive, we construct a compact bilayer SEI with a thin amorphous film covering a NP-packed layer structurally, promoting the uniform Li dissolution/deposition. This in situ AFM visualization in Li metal batteries highlights direct insights into distinct nanostructures and growth dynamics of nitrate-mediated SEI film at Li anode, and provides a universal and convenient technique for interfacial analysis and mechanistic understanding of Li metal anodes.

Tunable structure and property of SEI

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: In situ AFM characterization of the formation and evolution of SEI layer and dendritic nucleation of Li metal anode. (a) The voltage-time profile of the reaction processes. (b–d) SEI formation at OCP in baseline electrolyte. Inset of (b) shows Li surface before immersed into the electrolyte. (e–f) 3D images of SEI shrink upon dissolution in 1.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte. (g–i) 3D images of SEI and dendrite growth. (j–l) SEI growth at another dendritic Li. The arrows in (l) reveal the wrinkles on SEI. “E” means SEI, “S” means dissolution, and “P” means deposition. The scale bars are 1 μm in (b–d), 4 μm in (e–f), 2 μm in (g–i), 3 μm in (j) and 700 nm in (k–l).

In situ AFM characterization of the formation and evolution of the bilayer SEI in the electrolyte with 5.0 wt% LiNO3. (a–e) SEI formation at OCP. (f) The DMT modulus mapping of (e). (g–i) 3D images of Li interfacial evolution upon dissolution/deposition in 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte. The scale bars are 1 μm in (a–d), 300 nm in the insets of (d–e) and 2 μm in (e–i).

In situ AFM characterization of the formation and evolution of the SEI in the electrolyte with 7.5 wt% LiNO3. (a–c) SEI formation at OCP. (d–f) 3D images of Li interfacial evolution upon dissolution/deposition in 7.5 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte. The scale bars are 1 μm in (a–c) and 2 μm in (d–f).

In-depth analysis of the chemical components of the bilayer SEI. (a) The surface Li− distribution and (b) depth profiling by sputtering via ToF-SIMS. XPS spectra of (c) O 1s and (d) Li 1s recorded after different timings of argon ion sputtering of Li metal after soaked in 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte. (e) N 1s XPS spectra of Li samples soaked in electrolytes with different concentrations of LiNO3. The scale bar is 100 μm in (a).

Electrochemical characterization of Li anodes in various electrolytes. (a) Galvanostatic plating/stripping processes in Li symmetric cells. (b) The magnified voltage profiles of the 50th-53rd cycles. (c–e) SEM images of the Li electrodes after 500 cycles in the electrolytes of 1.0, 5.0, 7.5 wt% LiNO3, respectively. (f) Coulombic efficiencies of Li||Cu cells. The scale bars are 5 μm in (c–e).

Schematic diagrams of interfacial behaviors at Li metal anode. Electrolyte with 5.0 wt% LiNO3: (a) NP clusters with amorphous film deposit on Li surface. (b–c) The deposits rearrange into the amorphous-NP bilayer SEI. (d) Uniform Li deposits. Electrolyte with 1.0 wt% LiNO3: (e) Loose NPs nucleate on Li surface with amorphous film. (f) Inhomogeneous SEI forms. (g) Dendrite nucleates upon deposition and SEI grows at the dendrite. The SEI at the dendrite is colored in pink to distinguish with that at the surface. (h) Stress accumulates with chain-like wrinkles on the SEI.

head.ce:title: Tunable structure and dynamics of solid electrolyte interphase at lithium metal anode

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Interfacial processes of lithium (Li) deposition and solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation are key determinants of the safety and performance in high-energy Li metal batteries. With the vigorous growth of effective strategies for stabilizing the interfaces, high-resolution and in situ characterization techniques are contemporaneously needed for probing and regulating the underlying mechanisms of these two processes and their interrelation. Therefore, we introduce in situ atomic force microscopy (AFM) that enables direct observation of the nanoscale morphology and dynamic evolution of the Li/electrolyte interfaces in working environments. Inhomogeneous SEI with nanoparticles (NPs) forms in traditional electrolyte, which extends with chain-like wrinkles as dendrite nucleates. By precisely controlling the concentration of lithium nitrate additive, we construct a compact bilayer SEI with a thin amorphous film covering a NP-packed layer structurally, promoting the uniform Li dissolution/deposition. This in situ AFM visualization in Li metal batteries highlights direct insights into distinct nanostructures and growth dynamics of nitrate-mediated SEI film at Li anode, and provides a universal and convenient technique for interfacial analysis and mechanistic understanding of Li metal anodes.

Direct insights into the nanoscale SEI evolution at Li anode are provided inside working batteries using in situ AFM. LiNO3 presents straightforward SEI regulation. Compact bilayer SEI is built in 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte, however inhomogeneous one in 1.0 wt%. Noticeably, SEI on dendritic tip extends with radical chain-like wrinkles, revealing different dynamic features at surfaces/dendrites.
Image 1

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium (Li) metal, featuring the highest theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and the lowest electrochemical potential (−3.040 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode), is considered as the ultimate anode material for rechargeable batteries [1–3]. However, uncontrolled interfacial reactions of the chemically reactive Li hinder the commercial reality of Li metal batteries. The proliferation of dendritic electrodeposition at the Li metal anode causes internal short circuits and even safety hazards, making the Li metal into oblivion for several decades [4]. In recent years, researchers are reviving Li metal anode to meet the ever-increasing demands for high-energy transportation and storage [5]. Many efforts have been put to rationally designing Li/electrolyte interfaces for dendrite-free operation and realizing practical applications of high-energy Li metal batteries including Li-sulfur (Li–S) and Li-oxygen (Li–O2) batteries [6–9].

Tackling interfacial issues of Li metal anode is complex but important. The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) at Li metal anode plays the important role in regulating the transport and distribution of Li ions near the electrolyte/Li interface. Since the naturally formed SEIs are typically inhomogeneous in both morphology and composition, specific sites with locally enhanced current density and concentrated Li-ion flux, such as the tip position of the surface, become the fuse of heterogeneous Li nucleation and therefore dendritic growth [10–12]. Dendrite proliferates during cycling, which can break the fragile SEI and expose fresh Li to the electrolyte. The recovery of SEI depletes the electrolyte, while dendrite triggers short circuit. These two processes can occur in tandem, exacerbating the rapid cell failure. Besides, recent research shows that no preferential growth directions exist when Li nucleates. It is the anisotropic ion conductivity of the initial SEI guides subsequent Li deposition, which further confirms the decisive role of the SEI chemistry in the growth mode and morphology of Li metal [13].

Early in 1990s, Aurbach et al. firstly realized the interfacial visualization of Li metal anode in electrolyte environments via in situ atomic force microscopy (AFM), gaining our fundamental concept of SEI and localized interfacial morphology [14–16]. By cryo-scanning transmission electron microscopy (cryo-STEM), Kourkoutis et al. lately preserved the structures at the Li/electrolyte interfaces in their native states, enabling the structural and chemical mapping of the intact SEI and dendrite [17]. However, the dynamic interfacial changes, detailed nanostructures, key features, additive effects and the corresponding quantitative relationship of kinds of SEIs (mosaic and multilayer) remain unclarified. With the help of the increasingly sophisticated electrochemical AFM techniques, interesting works have been reported focusing on the SEIs on various electrodes of Li-ion batteries under diversified electrolyte systems [18–20]. The renaissance of high energy Li metal batteries including Li–S and Li–O2 batteries requests the fundamental interfacial understanding at Li metal anode, which is of vital importance to the interfacial electrochemistry of Li metal batteries.

Besides, the dominant components of SEI are decomposition products of electrolyte. Electrolyte modulation is frequently adopted as an effective, economical and feasible approach to stabilize SEI [21–23]. Lithium nitrate (LiNO3) has been widely regarded as a critical electrolyte additive in Li metal batteries, which participates in the Li ion solvation sheath and constructs “fast” SEI contributing to spherical Li deposition [24–27]. Systematic investigations of the LiNO3-mediated interfacial mechanism and nanoscale morphology-performance correlation are needed, targeting high-resolution real-time interfacial visualization and information of additive-involved SEIs.

Here, we present the morphological evolution at Li/electrolyte interfaces inside working batteries by in situ AFM, including the initial SEI formation at open circuit potential (OCP), as well as the dynamic contraction/extension upon Li dissolution/deposition. Inhomogeneous and amorphous SEI with loose nanoparticles (NPs) forms in the traditional electrolyte containing 1.0 wt% LiNO3, rendering the dendritic Li nucleation decorated with wrinkled SEI. Tuning effect of LiNO3 on the morphology and growth mode of SEI is presented. A dense and uniform SEI can be achieved when 5.0 wt% LiNO3 is added in the electrolyte, with a soft-stiff amorphous-NP bilayer structure, ensuring the stable interface and improved electrochemical performance after cycles. The evolution of the SEI changes from NP-expansion to NP-redistribution mode as LiNO3 increases from 1.0 to 7.5 wt%. The SEIs formed by NP-redistribution mode exhibit more compact morphology and beneficial components to suppress dendritic formation and facilitate ion transport. Using in situ AFM, we provide direct insights into the nanoscale morphological characteristics and evolution of SEIs at Li metal anodes, and the LiNO3-mediated mechanism over the physicochemical properties and dynamics, which affords interfacial visualization, mechanistic understanding and design guidance of Li metal batteries.

Lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI, purity >99.5%), 1,2-Dimethosyethane (DME), 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and sulfur (analytical reagent) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Lithium sulfide (Li2S, purity >99.9%) and LiNO3 (purity >99.98%) were from Alfa-Aesar. In the electrochemical cell, all of the electrodes were Li. Both the counter and the reference electrodes were Li strips. The Li foil was used as the working electrode. Before the in situ AFM observation, Li metal foil was polished with a sharp blade to remove the oxidized products on the surface and pressed into flat without evident scratches. The electrolytes were prepared by mixing stoichiometric amounts of Li2S and sulfur in 0.5 M LiTFSI in DOL/DME (1:1) with different concentrations of LiNO3.

Electrochemical AFM cell was assembled on the commercial AFM system (Bruker, Dimension ICON with Nanoscope V controllers) coupled with an electrochemical workstation for in situ electrochemical AFM experiments. The height-sensitive AFM with ever-growing techniques enables high-resolution visualization at the nanoscale even in the electrolyte environment [16,28,29]. All experiments were carried out in an argon-filled glovebox (MIKROUNA, Super 1220/750, H2O < 0.1 ppm, O2 < 0.1 ppm). Li surface was scanned by electrochemical AFM with a rectangular silicon AFM tip (force constant of 26 N m−1) in PeakForce Quantitative Nano Mechanics (QNM) mode.

Li anodes were separated from their respective cells at specific stages and dried in an argon-filled glovebox before the ex situ analyses. Time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) provided the elemental analysis and depth profiles of the Li anodes. The SIMS analysis was performed with a ToF-SIMS 5 instrument (ION-ToF GmbH, Münster, Germany) equipped with a 30 keV Bi3 + primary ion gun and a 2 keV Cs + sputter gun. An electron flood gun was used for charge neutralization. For surface analysis, the raster size of image was 500 × 500 μm2 with 256 × 256 pixels and sputter area was 650 × 650 μm2. For in-depth profiling, the raster size of image was 50 × 50 μm2 and sputter area was 200 × 200 μm2. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an ESCALab220i-XL electron spectrometer (VG scientific) using 300 W Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV). The base pressure was about 3 × 10−9 mbar, and the binding energies were referenced to the hydrocarbon C 1s peak at 284.8 eV.

The Li symmetric batteries were assembled with two Li disks in electrolytes with different concentrations of LiNO3. The batteries were tested at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 and a constant lithium deposition capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2 to evaluate the polarization and cycling stability. Similarly, Li||Cu cells were assembled to investigate the cycling reversibility. The current density is 1.0 mA cm−2 with the capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2. The morphology of the Li surface after cycling was then characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL 6701F) for comparison and explanation of the interfacial behaviours in different electrolyte environments.

ce:section.ce:section-title: In situ AFM study of SEI growth
ce:section.ce:para: For in situ AFM investigation, electrochemical cells are constructed using Li foil as the working electrode, Li strips as the counter and reference electrodes, illustrated in Fig. S1. LiTFSI (0.5 M) with Li2S8 (5 mM) in DOL/DME (1:1) is used as the baseline electrolyte, where Li2S8 is added to mimic the electrolyte environment in Li–S batteries and attenuate dendritic growth when coupled with LiNO3. The concentration of LiNO3 in electrolytes is the variable, which increases to mediate the microstructure, property and uniformity of SEI. Electrolyte reduction reactions take place instantly when Li metal contacts with the electrolyte, forming the ultrathin a-few-angstroms-thick SEI film via electron tunneling [30]. Yet, further SEI growth beyond tunneling-allowed distances, such as the intermediate product conversion and solvent diffusion, needs more time and contributes to the chemical and mechanical protective abilities of SEI, strongly depending on the electrolyte components [31,32]. As shown in Fig. S2, if dissolution/deposition processes start immediately after Li immersion into the electrolyte, pits initiate and increase upon Li dissolution, where fresh Li deposits rapidly and grows into sharp dendrite upon the subsequent deposition. Therefore, to better investigate the SEI growth and electrolyte effect, we performed the in situ AFM observation according to the following order: 4 h at OCP, 1 h dissolution and 1 h deposition with the current density of 3 mA cm−2 to detect the interfacial evolution in different electrolytes (Fig. 1 a). Li is initially dissolved to mimic the actual Li metal anode in Li–S cells [33].

Before the in situ study, the Li foil was carefully treated to remove the oxidized products on its surface. The inset of Fig. 1b presents the fresh and flat Li sample after the pretreatment. In the electrolyte without LiNO3, NPs (marked with arrows) nucleate along with the formation of amorphous deposits (marked with curves) in 15 min, and expand over time (Fig. 1b–c). More in situ and 3D images are shown in Fig. S3 to clearly reveal the morphological changes. From 0.5 to 4 h at OCP, the NPs expand with increase in statistical median thickness from 28.8 to 35.9 nm (Fig. 1d and Fig. S3m). This inhomogeneous SEI is fragile and cracked when Li dissolves, leading to the exposure of fresh bulk Li (Figs. S4a–c). Upon deposition, Li prefers to deposit on and integrate into the newly-exposed surfaces, further aggravating the surface roughness and the electrolyte consumption (Figs. S4d–f).

When 1.0 wt% LiNO3 is added into the electrolyte, similar NPs with larger size form and expand (in thickness from 65.4 to 89.9 nm) during OCP (Fig. S5). Though shrinks severely, the SEI is not damaged during dissolution (Fig. 1e–f and Figs. S6a–f). Upon deposition, bumps balloon underneath the SEI (Fig. 1g–i and Fig. S6g-l). Zoom-in images over an evident dendritic nucleus show detailed SEI features (Fig. 1j-l). Driven by the stress buildup, several chain-like wrinkles develop (marked in Fig. 1l), which deepen and elongate along the radial direction, just like the fissures around the crater. These bumps aggravate the interfacial heterogeneity, however the interface still shows improved uniformity with the flexible and adaptable SEI, which is beneficial to the interfacial control.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Tunable structure and property of SEI
ce:section.ce:para: Dendrites are not desired for the uniform interfaces. We increased the concentration of the LiNO3 in the electrolyte in an attempt to improve the property of SEI [34,35]. In the electrolyte containing 2.5 wt% LiNO3, the sizes of initial NPs decrease from 79.6, 56.5 to 26.7 nm after 15 min, 0.5 and 4 h at OCP (Figs. S7a–e). This dynamic change can be attributed to the chemical equilibrium of various reactions between the fresh Li and the electrolyte, including a sequence of deposition, dissolution and/or re-deposition processes, forming a more compact and stable structure that prevents further electrolyte permeation [31,36,37]. Upon the Li dissolution/deposition, the roughness increases because of the localized contraction/protrusion (Fig. S7f-m). Constructively, no evident dendrites are found.

When the concentration of LiNO3 is 5.0 wt%, clusters of NPs (in thickness of 156.5 nm) form with amorphous film covering the surface within 0.5 h (Fig. 2 a and Fig. S8a). They redistribute with size decreasing (Fig. S8b) and transform into a compact and smooth SEI layer composed of close-packed NPs (Fig. 2b–d). This uniform morphology remains as shown in the zoom-out image in Fig. 2e. An amorphous film is observed acting as a sub-layer on the NP-packed one (the inset of Fig. 2e). The DMT modulus image in Fig. 2f shows the different stiffness of these two sub-layers, with a clear interface as marked. Magnified topological and modulus images in Fig. S9 further confirm the co-existence of the soft amorphous and stiff NP-packed layers. In addition, we compared the mechanical strength of SEIs with inhomogeneous NPs and bilayer structure. As presented in Fig. S10, the modulus of the scattered, NP-decorated SEI lies in between the moduli of the amorphous top layer and NP-packed bottom layer. This indicates that the morphology uniformity plays a more vital role in interfacial stability of Li metal anode, which is consistent with a recent report based on finite element method (FEM) [38]. Therefore, thanks to the protection of the bilayer-structured SEI in 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte, the interface keeps integral with minimal increase of the roughness during the subsequent dissolution/deposition (Fig. 2g–i and Fig. S11).

Then 7.5 wt% LiNO3 is added into the electrolyte to further test the LiNO3 effect over SEI. Large NP clusters (in thickness of 339.9 nm) deposit within 5 min (Fig. 3 a). They transform into the relatively uniform morphology after 2 h with a NP-packed structure (85.4 nm thickness, Fig. 3b and Figs. S12a–d), whereas the even SEI cannot be maintained as new NP clusters form and remain thereafter (Fig. 3c and Figs. S12e–f). The accumulation of the NPs reflects the restricted ion movement with an increasing LiNO3 concentration [39], resulting in the rough surface. The non-uniform SEI cannot afford uniform ionic conductivity upon Li dissolution/deposition, resulting in the unstable interfacial evolution with increased roughness (Fig. 3d–f and Fig. S13).

By using in situ AFM, the interfacial processes of SEI formation and Li deposition/dissolution at Li metal anodes are visualized and elucidated. Two main points can be drawn from these findings. 1. Employing the 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte is the optimum scheme for the interfacial stability with bilayer-structured SEI. 2. In the electrolytes without and with 1.0 wt% LiNO3, loose NPs along with amorphous film deposit and expand at Li surfaces, forming the inferior SEIs. Stress-derived extension and wrinkling process of SEI are detected when dendrite nucleates in 1.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte. As the concentration of LiNO3 increases (from 2.5 to 7.5 wt%), NPs deposit in clusters at the beginning, and then redistribute into more compact structures. The corresponding thickness evolution processes are summarized in Fig. S14, which can be defined as NP-expansion and NP-redistribution modes. Further explorations are needed towards the in-depth understanding of the chemical property of the SEIs and LiNO3-mediated mechanism.

The element distribution on surface and in depth profiling can be monitored via ToF-SIMS [10,40]. The overlay image of Li− in Fig. 4 a indicates the homogeneous morphology of SEI at Li metal anode after immersed in the 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte for 4 h. The dynamic composition changes are obtained through in-depth analysis (Fig. 4b). Intensities of OH− and C2 − decrease at the initial sputter time of around 200 s, which slightly change and remain at low levels upon the later sputtering. Meanwhile, those of F−, CN−, and S− keep increasing in the inner region. Ions of OH− and C2 − represent the elements of O and C from the solvent decomposition, mainly found on the top organic-rich layer affording the good flexibility. And, ions of F−, CN−, and S− are on behalf of F, N and S, dominating the bottom inorganic-rich layer with strong mechanical property. Besides, in-depth XPS is performed to further investigate the spatial distribution of the compositions. As exhibited in Fig. 4c–d and Fig. S15a, organic species such as ROLi, ROCO2Li are the major components on the upper layer, while inorganic species such as Li2Sx, Li2SO3 and Li2O on the lower one [41,42], clarifying the benign interfacial protection from the organic-inorganic SEI.

Moreover, surface analyses of the SEI layers are realized by XPS in the electrolytes with different concentrations of LiNO3 (Fig. 4e and Figs. S15b–c), which reveal the LiNO3 effect on SEI in the combination with the in situ AFM results (illustrated in Fig. S16). It is reported that Li2S prefers to form on Li (110) rather than Li (111) [43], and the insulating nature of Li2S aggravates the inhomogeneous conductivity of the interfaces (Fig. S16a). The introduction of LiNO3 benefits solvent polymerization and increases organic moieties proportion in SEI (Fig. S15b) [44], which improves the flexibility of the SEI layer as the AFM results shown in the 1.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte. Besides, the reduction of LiNO3 supplies inorganic LiNxOy and Li2SOx to SEI (Fig. 4e and Fig. S15c), thickening the SEI film as measured in 1.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte (Fig. S16b).

Further increasing the LiNO3 amount to 2.5–7.5 wt% changes the SEI evolution from expansion mode to redistribution. The multi-step complex interfacial reactions cause deposition-dissolution-redeposition of the intermediate products, manifested as the redistribution. This explains the initially thicker SEIs become thinner over time in 2.5 and 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolytes. In addition, salt reduction reactions are more electron-involved when compared with solvent polymerization, and have to be processed in the region very close to Li [45], resulting in the SEI organic-inorganic delamination in 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte. The close packing of the NPs and uniform arrangement of all the chemicals in 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte contribute to the fine bilayer SEI, even thinner than that in 2.5 wt% (Figs. S16c–d). Nonetheless, excess nitrate species accumulate on the surface in 7.5 wt% case, blocking the ion diffusion with non-uniform SEI (Fig. 4e and Fig. S16e).

To verify the LiNO3-mediated mechanism, the electrochemical performances were examined in Li symmetric cells containing the electrolytes with different concentrations of LiNO3 at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 and a constant lithium deposition capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2. As exhibited in Fig. 5 a, the voltage profile of the cell in 1.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte shows the gradual increase from 200 to 350 cycles, which results from the uncontrolled SEI breakage and non-uniform Li growth. Fiber-like dendrites are observed via SEM imaging (Fig. 5c). In contrast, the voltage profile in 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte keeps stable over 500 cycles, displaying the lowest voltage polarization (Fig. 5a–b). Pancake-like Li particles are obtained in Fig. 5d, demonstrating the regulating effect of LiNO3 on the Li nucleation and growth. It is reported that low interfacial impedance and improved ion conductivity of the nitrated SEI facilitate Li plating on bulk surface, which suppress the subsequent Li insertion onto the tips/kinks of the existing protrusion, contributing to the unique pancake-like Li morphology [46]. In the electrolyte with 7.5 wt% LiNO3, the cell exhibits higher voltage polarization. Li deposits as the pancake-like morphology while with the relatively inhomogeneous distribution (Fig. 5e). In Fig. S17, the voltage profiles and Li images are collected from the cells in the electrolytes without and with 2.5 wt% LiNO3, which reveal the inferior interfacial stability with non-uniform Li deposition. In addition, Li||Cu cells are assembled to characterize the cycling reversibility. At the current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 and the capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2, the Coulombic efficiency values of Li anodes in the 5.0 and 7.5 wt% LiNO3 electrolytes maintain above 98% after 200 and 140 cycles, respectively (Fig. 5f). However, rapid drops occur in the cases in the other electrolytes. These performance results correlate well with the in situ AFM investigation and spectroscopic analysis, directly proving the vital function of LiNO3 in manipulating the SEI properties from the practical angle.

Therefore, the dynamic evolution of the SEI layers upon pristine formation at OCP and Li dissolution/deposition are visualized at nanoscale via in situ AFM observation. Besides, the LiNO3-mediated mechanism of SEI is presented in the combination of multi-scale techniques. In the electrolytes without and with 1.0 wt% LiNO3, inhomogeneous SEIs form at Li anodes from the expansion of loose NPs. Larger NP clusters deposit and redistribute towards denser structures as LiNO3 increases. Interestingly, when the concentration of LiNO3 is 5.0 wt%, clusters of NPs and amorphous products deposit at the interface first (Fig. 6 a). Then they get scattered and transform into a compact bilayer structure by redistribution (Fig. 6b–c), which shows the soft-stiff characteristic with an amorphous sub-layer covering a NP-packed one. Via in-depth spectroscopic analysis, we confirmed that it is organic-rich on the top and inorganic-rich on the bottom. The favorable concentration of LiNO3 brings appropriate interfacial reactions with balanced chemicals, structure and thickness of the durable SEI, contributing to the benign interface during Li dissolution/deposition (Fig. 6d). Continuing to increase the concentration of LiNO3, NPs accumulate with clusters remaining, increasing the surface roughness. The in situ observations of the Li/electrolytes interfaces directly describe the SEI formation and evolution inside working batteries. It is demonstrated that the morphology, dynamic evolution as well as the physicochemical property of SEI are regulated by the additive and its concentration in the electrolyte, providing the LiNO3-mediated mechanism over SEI and explicit structural-reactivity correlation.

Noticeably, detailed information of the real-time SEI evolution on Li dendrites is gained through in situ AFM investigation. Once fresh Li metal anode comes into contact with the 1.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte, amorphous film and loose NPs deposit, and expand at the interface (Fig. 6e–f), forming a non-uniform and fragile SEI. As illustrated in Fig. 6g, SEI tolerates protrusion enlargement because of its good tensile strength and continuous thickening via electrolyte reduction [36]. Tensile stress builds on the SEI layer, manifested as the wrinkles appear and deepen (Fig. 6h). This finding provides visual evidence of the SEI dynamics when dendrite grows, further proving that the homogeneous distribution of initial SEI layer is crucial for the uniform Li behaviors. It is worth mentioning that in situ formed SEIs can hardly realize perfectly structural uniformity [11,47]. They provide valuable information of the natural reactions between electrolytes and Li, which is essential to mechanism investigation. Synergetic strategies such as artificial engineering are recommended for stable Li metal anodes [7,48].

In summary, direct insights into the interfacial evolution at Li metal anodes and the LiNO3-mediated mechanism are disclosed. According to the in situ AFM monitoring, inhomogeneous SEIs with scattered NPs form in the electrolytes containing relatively low/high concentrations of LiNO3, which is responsible for the unstable Li behaviors and inferior battery performance. Gratifyingly, a soft-stiff bilayer SEI forms in the 5.0 wt% LiNO3 electrolyte, which consists of an amorphous film on the top and a NP-packed one on the bottom, ensuring the improved interfacial behavior during Li dissolution/deposition. As the concentration of LiNO3 increases, the evolution processes of SEIs change from NP-expansion to NP-distribution mode, which reveal the regulating role of LiNO3 in the structure and dynamics of SEI. Besides, key features of wrinkle-decorated SEI are presented on protrusion tips, lifting the veil on the high-resolution and in situ SEI imaging in their original states. Visualization via in situ AFM open a window to detect and manipulate the interfacial behaviors of Li anode at nanoscale, promoting the fundamental understanding of the intrinsic characters of SEI and can be widely spread in diversified advanced energy storage devices.

Shuang-Yan Lang: Conceptualization, Data curation, Formal analysis, Writing - original draft. Zhen-Zhen Shen: Data curation, Formal analysis. Xin-Cheng Hu: Methodology. Yang Shi: Methodology. Yu-Guo Guo: Resources. Fei-Fei Jia: Resources. Fu-Yi Wang: Resources. Rui Wen: Conceptualization, Writing - review & editing, Project administration, Supervision. Li-Jun Wan: Conceptualization, Writing - review & editing, Project administration, Supervision.
